bibl.title: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, March 5, 1942

div1.p: Jessie Ames will send Hench some of her husband's papers. She thinks the success of the yellow fever experiments depended on her husband and that he was not immune while he was nursing the volunteers. She was hurt by Kean and Ireland's lack of support for her husband being honored.

div1.head: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, March 5, 1942
div1.opener:
WILL W. ALEXANDER
EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
C. H. TOBIAS
ASSOCIATE DIRECTOR
M. ASHBY JONES, HONORARY PRESIDENT
HOWARD W. ODUM, PRESIDENT
CHARLES S. JOHNSON, FIRST VICE PRESIDENT
MRS. W. A. NEWELL, SECOND VICE PRESIDENT
RUFUS E. CLEMENT, THIRD VICE PRESIDENT
EMILY H. CLAY
SECRETARY · ASST. TREASURER
J. SHERRARD KENNEDY
TREASURER
Commission on Interracial Cooperation
INCORPORATED
710 STANDARD BUILDING
Atlanta, Georgia
March 5, 1942
R. B. ELEAZER
EDUCATIONAL DIRECTOR
MRS. JESSIE DANIEL AMES
GENERAL FIELD SECRETARY
TELEPHONE
WALNUT 7962
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Early next week, on Monday to be exact, I shall send you by express
a portfolio containing the data I have gathered and organized on
the record of my husband, Dr. Roger Post Ames, in the Army's fight
to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Congress and the public
that Yellow Fever was carried by mosquitoes.

I shall send a covering letter giving an index to the contents
with designations as to original records which you cannot find else-
where. These are, as you know, of great value to me and to my
family.

You have asked my opinion of the treatment accorded my husband.
Without this invitation from you, I should refrain from saying more
than is contained in the portfolio. Now, I shall express my opinion
anew.

I want to say first, however, that my husband did not talk about the
Cuba situation nor did he say anything explicit on the treatment
given him both by the Army and the Yellow Fever Board. He did speak
of Major Reed in terms of admiration and even affection. His remarks
on Dr. Carroll and Dr. Lazear were not as commendatory though I
cannot recall that there was anything personal in their tone. He
was not a man given to griping.

When Dr. Lazear died, the Board was left with no member who knew any
thing about Yellow Fever. That from the records. This was a bad
blow I think because the members had to turn to the only other person
who had experience and who could be depended upon to give an early
and correct diagnosis. The difficulty in this was that this other
meaning Ames
-2-
person was a young doctor, just turned thirty-one and a civilian to boot.
The Board wanted the credit for themselves and the Army. The members
looked with more than antagonism on the Public Health and Marine Hos-
pital Service, an antagonism which developed into downright jealousy
and bickering in the last epidemic in this country, New Orleans, in 1905.

Not a member of the Board had had Yellow Fever at that time nor did
Major Reed ever have it. Yet the success of the experiment depended
upon one expert who was not of them. He was not an immune as was later
proven by his contracting Yellow Fever while the experiment was going
on. It has always seemed to me that these two conditions colored
the attitude of the Board from the beginning. That is a young civilian
doctor and a non-immune upon whom they had to lean.

My husband was not appointed to fill the vacancy created by Dr. Lazear's
death. I think the conditions outlined above were the causes. Roger
was put in charge of the experimental cases; according to correspondence
included in the portfolio, he not only was in charge of the cases but he
assisted in selection of the men who submitted to the experimentation
and he innoculated them; checked the progress of the infection and
reported to Major Reed's headquarters when symptoms developed. His
success is shown in the records in the portfolio.
what proof?

As a reward for Roger's services he was commissioned a Captain and later
a Major of Volunteers, commission which were revoked when he was discharged
from the service after a term of service in the Philippines.

That the Army still depended upon him is evidenced by the fact that he was
ordered to Laredo, Texas when Yellow Fever broke there but this time
as a Contract Surgeon, a position viewed by the Army as neither fish -
flesh or good red herring. At Laredo he made his first contacts of
any importance with the Public Health and Marine Hospital Service.
After a successful career there during which he and I were married, he
was ordered to report for duty at Jackson Barracks to take over during
the Yellow Fever epidemic of 1905. It was there that there was real
trouble with both the officers at the Barracks and with the Army. This
was his trouble. The Army and the Marine Hospital Service mixed it also.

Of my own knowledge, I can state the following facts; Major Baily and
Dr. Little of Jackson Barracks wanted the troops moved. They did not
believe in the Yellow Fever mosquito theory. Upon my husband's advice,
they were kept at the Barracks. Colonel Maus was compelled to come over
in order to give authority to the advice of my husband. A contract
Surgeon has none, not even a reputation. As a result of the decision to
follow my husband's advice and because the Surgeon General and Colonel Kean
had complete confidence in my husband's ability to handle the situation,
a confidence born of the experiments in Cuba, the troops did stay. Both
Major Baily and Dr. Little placed every obstruction in the path of my
husband's work.

During the height of the epidemic, my husband took the soldiers on
excursions out to Lake Ponchetrain for recreation and possibly for their
morale. They returned always before dark, of course. This along with
other of his acts, kept the situation in the Barracks tense.

My opinion of the Yellow Fever Board and my conclusions on the reasons
why my husband was treated as he was were more than confirmed by two
interviews I had in Washington and by letters from Senator Sheppard of
Texas giving the results of interviews which he had.

Senator Sheppard found that there was no record of my husband's service
of any value in the War Department. He wrote me that he had his record
inserted. I don't know whether this was done or not. I know Senator
Sheppard thought it was. I wrote out an account of the interview with
Surgeon General Ireland immediately after I had it - a copy is in the
portfolio so I will not go into that.

I did not write out an account of the interview I had with Colonel Kean.
It was too painful. Though General Ireland's was no less brutal than
Colonel Kean's remarks they were not as painful, for Roger had not known
General Ireland nor had he counted him a friend. From Colonel Kean's
correspondence with my husband, some of the letters of which are included
in the portfolio, I had expected something different from him. However,
he belittled the service of my husband; he reproved me for seeking some
recognition of his services to the Yellow Fever Board when he told me
that my husband was a modest man who would be the last to approve of my
actions in trying to get such recognition; he said that there were others
who were left out of this field of recognition and that if they reopened
the list, it would be flooded with such people. Upon being pressed to
name more than two others, my husband and Mr. Lambert, he failed to give
a single name. He was somewhat peppery because I continued to insist at
this point. He said that when the lists were made up they had decided
the classes and that my husband did not fall into either class. He also
said, and this amazed me, that he had no idea that Roger had a family.
This amazed me because of correspondence from him in which he spoke of
“the bride.”

I think nothing quite so bowled me over as what I call Colonel Kean's
attitude toward my husband and his general belittling of him as well as
of his professional service. I have not spoken of this interview except
to one man whose friendship for Roger has lasted through all these years.
He told me, this friend, to go back and write out both interviews while
they were still fresh. I could not do that in the case of Major Kean.
I think that the only real hurt that was given me in this whole affair
came by way of Colonel Kean.

The slur on my husband's honesty, integrity, and honor given by both
Colonel Kean and General Ireland in their manner of speaking of the
Yellow Fever which my husband contracted did hurt. “The less said about
that the better” both told me, as though they had gotten to-gether on
their words.

I can understand now just why they said that. The one disquieting ele-
ment or rather the most disquieting element in the whole story was that
a non-immune civilian doctor took such enormous risks, risks that not
one of the Board would take. They chose to assume that being an immune
my husband was doing nothing specially dangerous. I am equally sure,
though this is not susceptible proof, that my husband did nothing to dis-
abuse their minds if he knew they were making such an assumption. If
he did not, it was not because he wanted to be a hero but because he
believed profoundly in the mosquito theory; he believed that he could
guard himself and escape infection; that he feared he might not be sent
to take over if it was known he had never had Yellow Fever. He had spent
all his professional life up to then in working with Yellow Fever. That
was in fact his specialty and he wanted to continue experimenting with
it until the theory was proven. These statements are made without any
other support than my knowledge of my husband.

There was doubt as to the way my husband contracted Yellow Fever. He
never told for his own reasons. Again I deduce he was conscious of having
been careless in the handling of infected mosquitoes. I do know that he
kept a “coop” of mosquitoes - Dr. Guiterriesas refers to the receipt of
such a coop in his letter to Roger. When he was at Fort McIntosh and
Fort St. Philip, I know that he fed those mosquitoes regularly by in-
serting his arm into the coop and letting them feed on his blood. I
know this because at the time, I was not only quite young in years but
I had been quite successfully protected from everything calculated as
crude or seamy by my father, and the very idea of his feeding mosquitoes
on his blood appalled and repelled me. I think that in the process of
keeping alive the mosquitoes needed for the experiment in Cuba he in-
advertently allowed himself to be bitten by an infected one. He would
not have admitted to this under any circumstances.

I tried to get both General Ireland and Colonel Kean to enlarge on their
remarks on his case of Fever but they would not. Incidentally both of
them did protest too much for the effect they hoped to attain. You see
though I was not acquainted with Roger during this period, I did not
know him and I did know his very unusual code of personal ethics. He
never claimed for himself anything to which he was not entitled and not
all of this and he did not lie. He could keep silent under the most
extraordinary pressure to make him talk.

It is my profound conviction that my husband has been done a grave injustice
and that he has been deprived of the recognition to which his service en-
titled him. I think that this would not have been done had he been alive
at the time official recognition was given the men in this work. I think
that this was done and is being done now because of the determination of
a certain group of men connected with the work to hold within the Army all
the credit and honor. In the case of Colonel Kean, this I conclude from
my interview with him, I think that he would have included Roger - for
Colonel Kean had the final decision on the personnel of those included -
had he been able to include his own name. He did say that he would like
to be one of them but he spent his time in Washington and could not
honestly say that he had anything to do with it. This does not read in
the way in which he spoke the words. His manner and his inflection cannot
be transcribed to paper.

I shall be glad to supplement the record I am sending you if you find
it incomplete and I have the lacking material.

closer.signed:
Jessie Daniel Ames
(Mrs. Roger Post Ames)
